class="grid">				<div class="grid-sm">					<article id="article-content" class="content"><section id="ref1" data-level="1"><p><strong><span id="ref365120"></span>Blaise Pascal</strong>,  (born June 19, 1623, Clermont-Ferrand, France—died <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/August" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="August">August</a> 19, 1662, Paris), French <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mathematics" class="md-crosslink">mathematician</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/physics-science" class="md-crosslink">physicist</a>, religious <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy" class="md-crosslink">philosopher</a>, and master of prose. He laid the foundation for the modern <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/probability-theory" class="md-crosslink">theory of probabilities</a>, formulated what came to be known as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/Pascals-principle" class="md-crosslink">Pascal’s principle</a> of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pressure" class="md-crosslink">pressure</a>, and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propagated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="propagated">propagated</a> a religious doctrine that taught the experience of God through the heart rather than through reason. The establishment of his principle of intuitionism had an impact on such later philosophers as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jean-Jacques-Rousseau" class="md-crosslink">Jean-Jacques Rousseau</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Henri-Bergson" class="md-crosslink">Henri Bergson</a> and also on the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/existentialism" class="md-crosslink">Existentialists</a>.</p><!--[P1]--><!--[ML1]--></section><!--[H2]--><section id="ref15001" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Pascal’s life to the Port-Royal years</h2><p>Pascal’s father, Étienne Pascal, was presiding judge of the tax court at <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Clermont-Ferrand" class="md-crosslink">Clermont-Ferrand</a>. His mother died in 1626, and in 1631 the family moved to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Paris" class="md-crosslink">Paris</a>. Étienne, who was respected as a mathematician, devoted himself henceforth to the education of his children. While his sister Jacqueline (born in 1625) figured as an infant <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/prodigy" class="md-crosslink">prodigy</a> in literary circles, Blaise proved himself no less <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/precocious" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="precocious">precocious</a> in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mathematics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mathematics</a>. In 1640 he wrote an <a href="https://www.britannica.com/art/essay" class="md-crosslink autoxref">essay</a> on <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/conic-section" class="md-crosslink autoxref">conic</a> sections, <em><span id="ref365121"></span>Essai pour les coniques</em>, based on his study of the now classical work of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Girard-Desargues" class="md-crosslink">Girard Desargues</a> on <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/synthetic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="synthetic">synthetic</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/projective-geometry" class="md-crosslink">projective geometry</a>. The young man’s work, which was highly successful in the world of mathematics, aroused the envy of no less a personage than the great French Rationalist and mathematician <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Rene-Descartes" class="md-crosslink">René Descartes</a>. Between 1642 and 1644, Pascal conceived and constructed a calculating device, the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/Pascaline" class="md-crosslink">Pascaline</a>, to help his father—who in 1639 had been appointed intendant (local administrator) at Rouen—in his tax computations. The <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/machine" class="md-crosslink autoxref">machine</a> was regarded by Pascal’s contemporaries as his main claim to fame, and with reason, for in a sense it was the first digital <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/calculator" class="md-crosslink">calculator</a> since it operated by counting <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/integer" class="md-crosslink">integers</a>. The significance of this contribution explains the youthful pride that appears in his dedication of the machine to the chancellor of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/France" class="md-crosslink autoxref">France</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Pierre-Seguier" class="md-crosslink">Pierre Seguier</a>, in 1644.</p><!--[P2]--><p>Until 1646 the Pascal family held strictly Roman Catholic principles, though they often substituted <em>l’honnêteté</em> (“polite respectability”) for inward <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/religion" class="md-crosslink">religion</a>. An illness of his father, however, brought Blaise into contact with a more profound expression of religion, for he met two <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/disciples" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="disciples">disciples</a> of the abbé de Saint-Cyran, who, as director of the convent of <span id="ref365122"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Port-Royal-abbey-Versailles-France" class="md-crosslink">Port-Royal</a>, had brought the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/austere" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="austere">austere</a> <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/moral" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="moral">moral</a> and theological <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conceptions" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="conceptions">conceptions</a> of <span id="ref365123"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Jansenism" class="md-crosslink">Jansenism</a> into the life and thought of the convent. Jansenism was a 17th-century form of Augustinianism in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Roman-Catholicism" class="md-crosslink">Roman Catholic Church</a>. It <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/repudiated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="repudiated">repudiated</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/free-will" class="md-crosslink">free will</a>, accepted <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/predestination" class="md-crosslink">predestination</a>, and taught that divine <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/grace-religion" class="md-crosslink">grace</a>, rather than good works, was the key to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/salvation-religion" class="md-crosslink">salvation</a>. The convent at Port-Royal had become the centre for the dissemination of the doctrine. Pascal himself was the first to feel the necessity of entirely turning away from the world to God, and he won his family over to the spiritual life in 1646. His letters indicate that for several years he was his family’s spiritual adviser, but the conflict within himself—between the world and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ascetic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="ascetic">ascetic</a> life—was not yet resolved. Absorbed again in his scientific interests, he tested the theories of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Galileo-Galilei" class="md-crosslink">Galileo</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Evangelista-Torricelli" class="md-crosslink">Evangelista Torricelli</a> (an Italian physicist who discovered the principle of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/barometer" class="md-crosslink">barometer</a>). To do so, he reproduced and amplified experiments on <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/atmospheric-pressure" class="md-crosslink autoxref">atmospheric pressure</a> by constructing <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mercury-chemical-element" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mercury</a> <span id="ref365124"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/barometer" class="md-crosslink">barometers</a> and measuring <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/air" class="md-crosslink">air</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pressure" class="md-crosslink">pressure</a>, both in Paris and on the top of a mountain overlooking Clermont-Ferrand. These tests paved the way for further studies in hydrodynamics and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/hydrostatics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">hydrostatics</a>. While experimenting, Pascal invented the <span id="ref365125"></span>syringe and created the <span id="ref365126"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/hydraulic-press" class="md-crosslink">hydraulic press</a>, an instrument based upon the principle that became known as <span id="ref365127"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/Pascals-principle" class="md-crosslink">Pascal’s principle</a>: pressure applied to a confined liquid is transmitted undiminished through the liquid in all directions regardless of the area to which the pressure is applied. His publications on the problem of the <span id="ref365128"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/vacuum-physics" class="md-crosslink">vacuum</a> (1647–48) added to his reputation. When he fell ill from overwork, his doctors advised him to seek distractions; but what has been described as Pascal’s “worldly period” (1651–54) was, in fact, primarily a period of intense scientific work, during which he composed <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/treatises" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="treatises">treatises</a> on the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equilibrium" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="equilibrium">equilibrium</a> of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/liquid-state-of-matter" class="md-crosslink">liquid</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/solution-chemistry" class="md-crosslink">solutions</a>, on the weight and density of air, and on the arithmetic triangle: <em>Traité de l’équilibre des liqueurs et de la pesanteur de la masse de l’air</em> (Eng. trans., <em><span id="ref365129"></span>The Physical Treatises of Pascal</em>, 1937) and also his <em><span id="ref365130"></span>Traité du triangle arithmétique</em>. In the last <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/treatise" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="treatise">treatise</a>, a fragment of the <em>De Alea Geometriae</em>, he laid the foundations for the calculus of probabilities. By the end of 1653, however, he had begun to feel religious scruples; and the “night of fire,” an intense, perhaps mystical “conversion” that he experienced on November 23, 1654, he believed to be the beginning of a new life. He entered Port-Royal in January 1655, and though he never became one of the solitaires, he thereafter wrote only at their request and never again published in his own name. The two works for which he is chiefly known, <em>Les Provinciales</em> and the <em>Pensées</em>, date from the years of his life spent at Port-Royal.</p><!--[P3]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="158630"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/11/150311-004-CF9CD502.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/11/150311-004-CF9CD502.jpg" alt="Blaise Pascal (centre) conducting experiments with a mercury barometer at a tower in Paris, engraving from La Nature, 1878." data-width="301" data-height="450"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Blaise Pascal (centre) conducting experiments with a mercury barometer at a tower in Paris, engraving from <em>La Nature</em>, 1878.</span><cite>© Photos.com/Thinkstock</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="3093"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/96/3396-004-B0463A4D.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/96/3396-004-B0463A4D.jpg" alt="Pascal, red crayon drawing by Jean Domat, c. 1649. In the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris." data-width="211" data-height="250"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Pascal, red crayon drawing by Jean Domat, <em>c.</em> 1649. In the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris.</span><cite>Courtesy of the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML3]--></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref15002" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><em><span id="ref365131"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Les-Provinciales" class="md-crosslink">Les Provinciales</a></em></h2><p>Written in defense of <span id="ref365132"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Antoine-Arnauld-French-theologian" class="md-crosslink">Antoine Arnauld</a>, an opponent of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Jesuits" class="md-crosslink">Jesuits</a> and a defender of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Jansenism" class="md-crosslink">Jansenism</a> who was on trial before the faculty of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/theology" class="md-crosslink">theology</a> in Paris for his controversial religious works, Pascal’s 18 <em>Lettres écrites par Louis de Montalte à un provincial</em> deal with divine <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/grace-religion" class="md-crosslink">grace</a> and the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ethical" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="ethical">ethical</a> code of the <span id="ref365133"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Jesuits" class="md-crosslink">Jesuits</a>. They are better known as <em>Les Provinciales</em> (“The Provincial Letters”). They included a blow against the relaxed <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/morality" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="morality">morality</a> that the Jesuits were said to teach and that was the weak point in their controversy with Port-Royal; Pascal quotes freely Jesuit <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dialogues" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="dialogues">dialogues</a> and discrediting quotations from their own works, sometimes in a spirit of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/derision" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="derision">derision</a>, sometimes with indignation. In the two last letters, dealing with the question of grace, Pascal proposed a conciliatory position that was later to make it possible for Port-Royal to subscribe to the “Peace of the Church,” a temporary cessation of the conflict over Jansenism, in 1668.</p><!--[P4]--><p>The <em>Provinciales</em> were an immediate success, and their popularity has remained undiminished. This they owe primarily to their form, in which for the first time bombast and tedious <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rhetoric" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="rhetoric">rhetoric</a> are replaced by variety, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/brevity" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="brevity">brevity</a>, tautness, and precision of style; as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Nicolas-Boileau" class="md-crosslink">Nicolas Boileau</a>, the founder of French <a href="https://www.britannica.com/art/literary-criticism" class="md-crosslink autoxref">literary criticism</a>, recognized, they marked the beginning of modern French prose. Something of their popularity, moreover, in fashionable, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Protestant-Heritage-1354359" class="md-crosslink">Protestant</a>, or skeptical circles, must be attributed to the violence of their attack on the Jesuits. In England they have been most widely read when <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Roman-Catholicism" class="md-crosslink">Roman Catholicism</a> has seemed a threat to the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Church-of-England" class="md-crosslink">Church of England</a>. Yet they have also helped Catholicism to rid itself of laxity; and, in 1678, Pope <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Blessed-Innocent-XI" class="md-crosslink">Innocent XI</a> himself condemned half of the propositions that Pascal had denounced earlier. Thus, the <em>Provinciales</em> played a decisive part in promoting a return to inner religion and helped to secure the eventual triumph of the ideas set forth in Antoine Arnauld’s treatise <em><span id="ref365134"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/De-la-frequente-communion" class="md-crosslink">De la fréquente communion</a></em> (1643), in which he protested against the idea that the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/profligate" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="profligate">profligate</a> could atone for continued <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/sin-religion" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sin</a> by frequent communion without repentance, a thesis that thereafter remained almost unchallengeable until the French church felt the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/repercussion" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="repercussion">repercussion</a> of the revocation of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Edict-of-Nantes" class="md-crosslink">Edict of Nantes</a> (which had granted religious freedom to French Protestants) in 1685. Whereas the Jesuits seemed to represent a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Counter-Reformation" class="md-crosslink">Counter-Reformation</a> predominantly concerned with orthodoxy and obedience to <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ecclesiastical" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="ecclesiastical">ecclesiastical</a> authority, the <em>Provinciales</em> advocated a more spiritual approach, emphasizing the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/soul-religion-and-philosophy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">soul’s</a> union with the Mystical Body of Christ through charity.</p><!--[P5]--><p>Further, by rejecting any <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/bimetallism" class="md-crosslink autoxref">double standard</a> of morality and the distinction between <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/counsel" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="counsel">counsel</a> and precept, Pascal aligned himself with those who believe the ideal of evangelical perfection to be inseparable from the Christian life. Although there was nothing original in these opinions, Pascal nevertheless stamped them with the passionate <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conviction" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="conviction">conviction</a> of a man in love with the absolute, of a man who saw no <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/salvation-religion" class="md-crosslink">salvation</a> apart from a heartfelt desire for the truth, together with a love of God that works continually toward destroying all self-love. For Pascal, morality cannot be separated from spirituality. Moreover, his own spiritual development can be traced in the <em>Provinciales</em>. The religious sense in them becomes progressively refined after the first letters, in which the tone of ridicule is smart rather than charitable.</p><!--[P6]--></section><!--[H4]--><section id="ref15003" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><em><span id="ref365135"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Pensees" class="md-crosslink">Pensées</a></em></h2><p>Pascal finally decided to write his work of Christian <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/apologetics" class="md-crosslink">apologetics</a>, <em>Apologie de la religion chrétienne</em>, as a consequence of his meditations on miracles and other proofs of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Christianity" class="md-crosslink">Christianity</a>. The work remained unfinished at his death. Between the summers of 1657 and 1658, he put together most of the notes and fragments that editors have published under the inappropriate title <em>Pensées</em> (“Thoughts”). In the <em>Apologie</em>, Pascal shows the man without <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/grace-religion" class="md-crosslink">grace</a> to be an incomprehensible mixture of greatness and abjectness, incapable of truth or of reaching the supreme good to which his nature nevertheless aspires. A <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/religion" class="md-crosslink">religion</a> that accounts for these contradictions, which he believed <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy" class="md-crosslink">philosophy</a> and worldliness fail to do, is for that very reason “to be venerated and loved.” The indifference of the <span id="ref365136"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/skepticism" class="md-crosslink">skeptic</a>, Pascal wrote, is to be overcome by means of the “<span id="ref365137"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Pascals-wager" class="md-crosslink">wager</a>”: if God does not exist, the skeptic loses nothing by believing in him; but if he does exist, the skeptic gains eternal life by believing in him. Pascal insists that men must be brought to God through <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jesus" class="md-crosslink">Jesus Christ</a> alone, because a creature could never know the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/infinite" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="infinite">infinite</a> if Jesus had not descended to assume the proportions of man’s fallen state.</p><!--[P7]--><p>The second part of the work applies the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Augustinians" class="md-crosslink">Augustinian</a> theory of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/art/allegory-art-and-literature" class="md-crosslink">allegorical</a> interpretation to the biblical types (<em>figuratifs</em>); reviews the rabbinical texts, the persistence of true religion, the work of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Moses-Hebrew-prophet" class="md-crosslink">Moses</a>, and the proofs concerning Jesus Christ’s God-like role; and, finally, gives a picture of the primitive church and the fulfillment of the prophecies. The <em>Apologie (Pensées)</em> is a treatise on spirituality. Pascal was not interested in making converts if they were not going to be <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/saint" class="md-crosslink">saints</a>.</p><!--[P8]--><p>Pascal’s apologetics, though it has stood the test of time, is primarily addressed to individuals of his own acquaintance. To convert his libertine friends, he looked for arguments in their favourite authors: in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Michel-de-Montaigne" class="md-crosslink">Michel de Montaigne</a>, in the Skeptic <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Pierre-Charron" class="md-crosslink">Pierre Charron</a>, in the Epicurean <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Pierre-Gassendi" class="md-crosslink">Pierre Gassendi</a>, and in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Hobbes" class="md-crosslink">Thomas Hobbes</a>, an English political philosopher. For Pascal, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/skepticism" class="md-crosslink">Skepticism</a> was but a stage. Modernist theologians in particular have tried to make use of his main <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/contention" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="contention">contention</a>, that “man is infinitely more than man,” in isolation from his other contention, that man’s wretchedness is explicable only as the effect of a Fall, about which a man can learn what he needs to know from history. In so doing, they sacrifice the second part of the <em>Apologie</em> to the first, keeping the philosophy while losing the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/exegesis" class="md-crosslink autoxref">exegesis</a>. For Pascal as for <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Paul-the-Apostle" class="md-crosslink">St. Paul</a>, Jesus Christ is the second <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Adam-and-Eve-biblical-literary-figures" class="md-crosslink">Adam</a>, inconceivable without the first.</p><!--[P9]--><p>Finally, too, Pascal expressly admitted that his psychological analyses were not by themselves sufficient to exclude a “philosophy of the absurd”; to do so, it is necessary to have recourse to the convergence of these analyses with the “lines of fact” concerning revelation, this convergence being too extraordinary not to appear as the work of providence to an anguished seeker after truth (<em>qui cherche en gémissant</em>).</p><!--[P10]--><p>He was next again involved in scientific work. First, the “Messieurs de Port-Royal” themselves asked for his help in composing the <em>Élements de géométrie</em>; and second, it was suggested that he should publish what he had discovered about <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/cycloid" class="md-crosslink">cycloid</a> curves, a subject on which the greatest <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mathematics" class="md-crosslink">mathematicians</a> of the time had been working. Once more fame aroused in him feelings of self-esteem; but from February 1659, illness brought him back to his former frame of mind, and he composed the “prayer for conversion” that the English clergymen <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Charles-Wesley" class="md-crosslink">Charles</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Wesley" class="md-crosslink">John Wesley</a>, who founded the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Methodism" class="md-crosslink">Methodist Church</a>, were later to regard so highly. Scarcely capable of regular work, he henceforth gave himself over to helping the poor and to the ascetic and devotional life. He took part intermittently, however, in the disputes to which the “Formulary”—a document condemning five propositions of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Jansenism" class="md-crosslink">Jansenism</a> that, at the demand of the church authorities, had to be signed before a person could receive the sacraments—gave rise. Finally a difference of opinion with the theologians of Port-Royal led him to withdraw from controversy, though he did not sever his relations with them.</p><!--[P11]--><p>Pascal died in 1662 after suffering terrible pain, probably from carcinomatous <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/meningitis" class="md-crosslink">meningitis</a> following a malignant <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/ulcer" class="md-crosslink">ulcer</a> of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/stomach" class="md-crosslink">stomach</a>. He was assisted by a non-Jansenist parish priest.</p><!--[P12]--></section><!--[H5]--><section id="ref15004" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Legacy</h2><p>At once a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/physics-science" class="md-crosslink">physicist</a>, a mathematician, an <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/eloquent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="eloquent">eloquent</a> publicist in the <em>Provinciales</em>, and an inspired artist in the <em>Apologie</em> and in his private notes, Pascal was embarrassed by the very abundance of his talents. It has been suggested that it was his too concrete turn of mind that prevented his discovering the infinitesimal <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/calculus-mathematics" class="md-crosslink">calculus</a>; and in some of the <em>Provinciales</em> the mysterious relations of human beings with God are treated as if they were a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/geometry" class="md-crosslink">geometrical</a> problem. But these considerations are far outweighed by the profit that he drew from the multiplicity of his gifts; his religious writings are rigorous because of his scientific training; and his love of the concrete emerges no less from the stream of quotations in the <em>Provinciales</em> than from his determination to reject the vigorous method of attack that he had used so effectively in his <em>Apologie</em>.</p><!--[P13]--><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Jean-Orcibal/2206">Jean Orcibal</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/Lucien-Jerphagnon/1479">Lucien Jerphagnon</a></span><span class="md-signature"><a href="/editor/The-Editors-of-Encyclopaedia-Britannica/4419">The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica</a></span></section><!--[END-OF-CONTENT]--></article><div class="md-learn-more extra-content" data-module="learn-more" data-value="learn-more">        <h2>Learn More <span>in these related Britannica articles:</span></h2>        <ul>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/topic/history-of-Europe/The-proto-Enlightenment#ref310911">                    <div class="image-wrapper text-center">                            				<img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/180x300/52/120252-004-60691816.jpg"  alt="Encyclopædia Britannica: first edition, map of Europe" />	</div>                    <div class="title"><strong>history of Europe: The proto-Enlightenment</strong></div>                    <div class="description"><strong>Blaise Pascal</strong> had perfectly exemplified that rationalist frame of mind prone to introspection, which in his case—that of mathematical genius and literary sensibility in rare combination—produced some of the finest writing of his day.
